Posts.Content: I know how you feel. One friend nipped in to see me on her way home from Shropshire to Nottingham (I live in Preston), whilst another passes the end of my street to go to work and I've not seen her in the 3 weeks since my mastectomy. Other friends have brought meals, one cycling in the rain as her car was in the garage. This journey has made me think about how I will look after friends who need my help in the future. Actions speak louder than words. Anita

Posts.Title: when does your hair come back

Posts.Content: Hi I took Tamoxifen prior to having surgery and before chemotherapy. I've had my last chemo today so the Oncologist is going to restart it in a couple of weeks. Last time I took it at night time because it made me feel slightly nauseous and I could cope with that better when lying flat in bed. Posts.Title: tamoxifen advice

Posts.Content: My surreal world just gets worse. 3 months ago I found a lump that doctors assured me was 'normal breast tissue', but they would investigate it just to be sure. On mammo, ultrasound and MRI it looked harmless, but thankfully they did a core biopsy. 2 weeks ago my surgeon couldn't find my lump pre-op as it had shrunk significantly after 1 month of Tamoxifen. I was in theatre for 3 hours having a WLE and SNB. My notes also said that 1 'palpable' node was removed. Yesterday I saw the BCN (with my 19 year daughter, on the day of her A level results, as my husband was at work) to be told that they had removed a 55mm lump and the edges showed signs of pre-cancerous cells and the node was also affected. Now I need a mastectomy, chemotherapy and radiotherapy. We have to decide whether to have the chemo or the surgery first. I'm thinking that I will have the chemo first, but that decision is based purely on the fact that I'm scared of the surgery! I have good friends and a supportive family who say we'll do this together, so perhaps one of them will have the mastectomy for me! They also try to reassure me that life will get back to 'normal'. What I do know is that at 2.40am I would rather be sleeping than posting on here! Take care Anita
Posts.Title: Its life Jim, but not as we know it

Posts.Content: Hi. I can only suggest that you keep talking to the doctors. I have ulcerative colitis which had been flaring up prior to commencing my chemo. The first lot of chemo made me neutropenic and I couldn't cope with the colitis as well. I ended up being admitted for iv antibiotics and steroids. The advantage is that now both my consultants are discussing my case and treating me as a whole person with 2 tedious diseases and not 2 completely separate issues. I had my 2nd lot of chemo yesterday - my regime has been reduced to 'EC' (the F has been removed and E reduced, althoufgh I've been reassured it will still be effective). I feel fine today with none of the symptoms from last time. Good luck
Posts.Title: New to the Group worrying about the whole Breast Cancer situation...

Posts.Content: Hi Tracie The year you described reminded me of 1992. We started the year having a premature baby who died, followed by a car accident, my husband fell off his motorbike, I was diagnosed with ulcerative colitis and my Grandma died . By the end of the year I had a new car, hubby had recovered from his injuries, the colitis was stabilised and I was pregnant again. The point I'm trying to make is that life moves on and it isn't always as bad as it seems at the moment. Gradually other things will become more important in our lives than this damned disease. Just remember you've had an enormous amount to put up with over the last few months and you're still strong. I don't think you're being paranoid as it perfectly acceptable to have some worries about the cancer spreading, but we need to keep that in perspective and not let it take over our lives. I have been off work since the end of July and I don't anticipate going back until I've finished radiotherapy scheduled for Feb/March. I do miss work, but I don't feel that I could manage it at the moment, especially whilst having sleepless nights due to steroids. Make sure you are ready to go back and I assume they have you on a phased return to work in case you can't manage the 24 hours. You may find that you find more energy from doing something. Just take care of yourself xx Anita
Posts.Title: Feeling paranoid, dare I think of a future

Posts.Content: Glad you're home and doing okay with plenty of support. I had my mastectomy 4 weeks ago and now I'm fine from that, although I've started chemo now (yuck). My consultant wouldn't do the reconstruction at the same time as the mastectomy as I need radiotherapy and he said it could spoil the results of the reconstruction so I'll have to decide this time next year if I want further surgery. It seems different in each region doesn't it? Take care and rest. Make use of your wonderful support. Anita x
Posts.Title: home after masectomy

Posts.Content: Hi. I asked my oncologist if I would be scanned. At our local trust it depends on how many positive lymph nodes were found. Less than 4 is classed as okay and 4 or more gets a CT scan. I only had 1 lymph node affected from the 40 they took out so no scan for me. We just have to live with the aches and pains that we had before diagnosis and reassure ourselves we haven't got mets everywhere. This can be difficult sometimes. Anita
Posts.Title: How do I know if its spread?

Posts.Content: I wish we could have a 'like' button on this site! I've been off work since the end of July (I'm also a nurse) and after lumpectomy, mastectomy and node clearance all being well I'm having my last chemo tomorrow. Just radiotherapy now and then I can start thinking about getting back to work. It is great to be getting towards the end of the journey. I can't say it has been easy and I've had several admissions to hospital with neutropenia and spent 2 weeks over Christmas and New Year in hospital with PCP. When I got home I had so many emails it was difficult to catch up and I have not contributed to the site for some time. I send my best wishes to Jackie and I'm sure she'll soon get back into nursing and 'normal' life. Anita
Posts.Title: Turning Corners and a Bit of Inspiration :-)

Posts.Content: Hi Chodgy. I've been off work since the end of July and a colleague within the organisation (not doing the same role) had 12 months off work whilst having treatment. I go on to half pay this month so I'll have to see how that works out. I stopped work a few days before my lumpectomy, because I was having regular visits to outpatients for pre-op assessments, ultrasounds, CT scans etc. My original treatment plan was to have a lumpectomy followed by radiotherapy so I thought I would work on the days I could manage and my line manager was willing to support me in this. Following my lumpectomy my GP surprised me by signing me off for 3 months to cover the time I would be having radiotherapy without questioning it. Unfortunately my treatment plan has changed and 4 weeks after the lumpectomy I had a mastectomy then 4 weeks following that I started chemo. The Oncologist does not want me to work as I am an Infection Prevention Nurse and visit areas with outbreaks and patients with infection. As I have had various side effects including neutropenia on almost every cycle I would not have been able to work anyway. Some days I feel great and meet friends for lunch etc and had a short break with my hubby. I do feel guilty on these days but they are few and far between! The 3 month sick note has been repeated by another GP, but my current sick note is only for 6 weeks and runs out at the during my radiotherapy treatment, so I've made an appointment to discuss with my GP about returning to work. Mum suffers from dementia and is in a care home and I'm not visiting her as much as I used to and avoiding the first week or so after chemo because of my problems with neutropenia Anyway, we are not funded at the tax payers expense. It is out of the public purse which is a fund that we all contribute towards in different ways and it should be viewed as an insurance for people who need it. Anita
Posts.Title: Fit notes

Posts.Content: Hi - I also got my results on Tuesday and again all the professionals and tests suggested that it was normal breast tissue. As I've had several benign lumps in the past I wasn't too worried. My results have come as a surprise to everyone. I need scans etc before they decide the extent of surgery and further treatment. In the meantime I'm off to Corsica tomorrow for a long awaited family holiday, I've been commenced on Tamoxifen and everyone says it is ok to go as I've started treatment, but it means the investigations (and therefore the surgery) will be delayed by a couple of weeks. My head is in a whirl. I want to know everything, but when I look at the internet I'm not sure what I need to know. Anita
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed!

Posts.Content: On the day I was discharged from hospital one of my dear friends had been round to the house with a cottage pie (despite the fact that she is vegan!) and a crumble. What a star! My brother has also collected me a couple of times to take me to visit Mum in the Nursing Home. I am so grateful for these small examples of kindness and it has made me think about how I will support family and friends who are having any health problems in the future.

Posts.Title: Not great scan results :(

Posts.Content: Hi Lynn I'm also awake and reading your post. What a steamroller of a ride you've been on. Thank goodness you went for your routine mammogram as it shows that everyone does not present with recognised symptoms, but these developments must be difficult to comprehend. I think it is the speed that things change that is alarming. You enter the Consulting Room expecting some news and a few minutes later you leave the room with your world turned upside down. Like you say the scan is being done quickly and then you can have a treatment plan. I felt better once I had a plan of action and although it hasn't been easy I've been able to break the journey into stages so at least I can see an end to each stage. Sending you hugs and I'll be thinking about you today. Take care Anita xx
Posts.Title: Can't believe this

Posts.Content: Hi Kiera I think I know how you feel as I was in a similar position in August. I had a small lump that was disappearing with tamoxifen but when they did the lumpectomy and removed the nodes I had 55cm of invasive lobular, invasive ductal and DCIS with no clear margins. I also had 1 node affected. I couldn't sleep and I would cry at unexpected times, which isn't like me! Whilst I didn't think my time was up the thought of surgery and chemo did not appeal. Anyway, I had my mastectomy at the beginning of September and now I'm half way through my chemotherapy. Whilst I am not exactly sailing through the treatment neither have been the ordeal that I imagined they would be. I just keep thinking that only 1 node was affected and the chemo and radiotherapy are my insurance policy to be extra sure that they have killed off any little seedlings that may be there. Big hugs and good luck tomorrow Anita xxxx
Posts.Title: Finding it hard to cope

Posts.Content: 4 weeks since diagnosis. I've got my appointment with the Consultant today to discuss surgical options. I just keep singing the lyrics to Move in the Right Direction by Gossip. Anita
